div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin May 21st 1915
div1.p: Honestly I didn’t complain to Rockwell about the number of times you had written. I remarked at the time I sent him the comment that you hadn’t written at all. You hadn’t up until then, you know. You’ve been very sweet about letting me hear from you and I appreciate it thoroughly. Besides even if I was disappointed I would never say so to you or ask you to write more. I’ve had three letters from you now and I’ve spent three happy weeks reading and rereading them.

Poor old Paul Rockwell
is having a hard time of it. First his fiancee gets ill and then his brother is wounded. Still taking everything into consideration I think his brother’s case is fortunate. He was in a terrible fight at Arras. The regiment fought for five hours. The whole thing was wiped out with the exception of two hundred, all of whom were wounded. Kiffin was lucky to be in the two hundred, and still more fortunate in getting wounded only by a bullet. He’s at Reimes [sp?] now in Bretagne. I suppose I’ll get it worse
than that before we finish, but of course one cannot tell.

Curtin will give you news of us soon. He’s leaving for America as soon as he can get his discharge. His family has recalled him. I hate to see him go for I like him immensely. He has come nearer to getting killed than any of us. A 220 shell hit ten feet from him but failed to detonate. If it had we would have peeled him off the wall and sent him home in an envelope. He will leave in about two weeks.
Two fellows and I are to start a service in a few days that I think is unique. We are to take the place of the stretcher two wheeled carts and run up into the woods getting the wounded and taking them to the different Postes de Secours. Our ambulance will then take them to hospitals as usual. We come in for a bit of rifle fire on the route.

Rockwell wrote me saying he hadn’t seen you and added “I wish to see her tho [sic] for she is a dandy girl.” Our tastes are congenial you will please note.
Both Curtin and Lovell feel ashamed that they haven’t written to you but it is very hard to find the time. Six new cars and drivers are here now and we may have more leisure. The new crowd is beginning the regular Oh - lead - me - to the -shells, - and - I’ll -stand on -the - roof, talk. Wait. The little ones, the 77s aren’t so bad, but when the marmites come in its a different story. One landed on a house two nights ago and after that there wasn’t anything that resembled a house.
Rockwell is going back to the front in three months, I am sorry to say. He insists on another whack at the brutes.
The French have been accomplishing fine things where we are and better results will soon follow. Vive la France! Eh [sic] Mlle. Marcelle Guerin?

closer.salute: Take good care of your dear self and the best of wishes.
